The ASSISTANT COACH, HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL role at Hilltop Service Center is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the ASSISTANT COACH, HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Hilltop Service Center are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The ASSISTANT COACH, HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the ASSISTANT COACH, HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The ASSISTANT COACH, HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Hilltop Service Center, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the ASSISTANT COACH, HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL at Hilltop Service Center, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The MIDDLE SCHOOL COACH position at Athletic Bldg is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The MIDDLE SCHOOL COACH is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Athletic Bldg, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The MIDDLE SCHOOL COACH encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The MIDDLE SCHOOL COACH also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the MIDDLE SCHOOL COACH role at Athletic Bldg is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The Boys Lacrosse - Varsity Assistant Coach position at Summit High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. At Summit High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Boys Lacrosse - Varsity Assistant Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Boys Lacrosse - Varsity Assistant Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.

Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Assistant Coach- Baseball- HS is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Castle View High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Assistant Coach- Baseball- HS encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Assistant Coach- Baseball- HS also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Assistant Coach- Baseball- HS role at Castle View High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The Head Track Coach position at Canon City Middle School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Head Track Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.

At Canon City Middle School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Head Track Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Head Track Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.

Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The High School Assistant Girls Basketball Coach at Ellicott High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the High School Assistant Girls Basketball Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Ellicott High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The High School Assistant Girls Basketball Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The High School Assistant Girls Basketball Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Ellicott High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Ellicott High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the High School Assistant Girls Basketball Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the High School Assistant Girls Basketball Coach role at Ellicott High School.

Athletic Trainer
EDUCATION AND EXPERIENCE: A minimum of a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university and meets certification requirements as established by the Board of Certification for Athletic Trainers as well as the Georgia Department of Education and the Local Unit of Administration (LUA).
CERTIFICATES, LICENSES, PERMITS: Valid State of Georgia Athletic Trainer License and Georgia Professional Standards Commission certificate.
QUALIFICATIONS: Incumbent must be able to satisfactorily perform each essential function of the position. When appropriate, reasonable accommodations will be provided to afford persons with disabilities an opportunity to perform the essential functions of the position. Incumbent must be able to provide a Criminal Background Check with results that adhere to Emanuel County Board of Education Policy GAK(1). Incumbent must have knowledge of subject matter and appropriate instructional methodologies. Ability and training necessary to effectively utilize technology in the planning, implementation, and evaluation of instruction. Evidence of exemplary human relation skills. Evidence of exemplary organization and planning skills. Evidence of ability to work effectively with students, parents, and staff.
ATHLETIC TRAINING PERFORMANCE FUNCTIONS: Demonstrates the ability to: Use tact, discretion, initiative and independent judgment within established guidelines. Organize work, set priorities, meet critical deadlines and follow up on assignments with a minimum of direction. Communicate clearly and effectively, orally and in writing. Work collaboratively with a broad and diverse population of students, families, peers and colleagues. Hold knowledge of universal hygiene precautions. Hold knowledge and training in first aid procedures required for handling athletic related injuries. Be able to work within various degrees of noice, temperature and air quality. Work surfaces will vary from concrete to grass to hardwood floors. Job responsibilities require both inside and outside assignments. Interruptions of work are routine. Flexibility and patience are required. Must be self motivated and able to complete job assignments without direct supervision. After hours work is required. Must be able to work under stressful conditions. Be able to assist with or transfer athletes of various weights/heights. Be able to push carts with athletic equipment on them. Be able to demonstrate the ability to communicate to give adequate directions and instructions to subordinates. Be able to carry training kit and coolers for long distances.
ATHLETIC TRAINER SPECIFIC RESPONSIBILITIES: Responsible for prevention, emergency care, first aid, evaluation and rehabilitation of injuries to athletes under his/her care. Serve as a liaison between the team physician, the athlete, the athlete's parents and coaching staff. Consultant to coaching staff on conditioning, nutrition, and protective equipment. Assist with prevention of injuries including education for athletes and athletic trainers, identifying factors that put athletes "at risk", correcting deficiencies in athletes as deemed necessary, as well as taping and bracing. Provide emergency care and first aid including availability of necessary equipment, communication procedures for emergency situation and prompt accurate triage. Evaluate acute and chronic injuries and refer to the team physician or specialist where appropriate. Help decide if a play may return to competition following an injury. Treat athletic injuries with protection, rest, ice, compression, evaluation, support, ultrasound, electrical stimulation, cold/heat and hydrotherapy as needed or prescribed with the availability of modalities. Develop, supervise, evaluate and modify individual exercise programs for rehabilitation to help athletes return to a pre-injury status. Maintain records including injury reports, home care instructions, referrals, treatments records, rehabilitation progress notes and insurance information. Secure training room equipment and supplies as needed. Provide education and supervision for athletes and students. Cover team practices allowing access to the athletic training room. Cover sporting events as scheduled with the athletic director. Establishment of a positive learning environment that promotes a high level of achievement for all students while considering the background and developmental level of individual students. Prepares and maintains a variety of reports, correspondence and notices. Maintains accurate and complete student documentation as required by law, district policy and administrative regulations. Attends conferences, workshops and other professional development to maintain current knowledge of the profession. Maintains appropriate levels of confidentiality. Collaborates with school personnel to develop school-wise initiatives to make schools safer and more effective. Make the training room facilities and medical attention available to school athletes with arrangements made by the coach and the athletic trainer.
PERFORMANCE FACTORS: Medium Work: Exerting up to 50 pounds of force occasionally and/or up to 20 pounds of force frequently, and/or up to 10 pounds of force constantly to move objects.

Job.JobDescription:
Job Summary
Administers all aspects of sports specific activity within the District and individual school's Athletic Department policy, as well as, within the guidelines of the Florida High School Athletics Association and the National Federation High Schools.
Essential Functions
1. Announce and enforce rules pertaining to conditioning of players and the training rules affecting the health and safety of the players. Ascertain that the EL2, EL3, Insurance Verification, Sportsmanship contract, birth certificate and other forms are on file for all team members. 2. Cooperate with the athletic director in establishing physical examinations and verify that no candidate is issued equipment, allowed to practice or condition until the DCPS Athletic Health Examination Form is completed in full and signed by the athlete, parent/guardian and physician. 4. Conduct and supervise at least one fund raising activity for his or her sport. 5. Ensure the team is supervised at all times. This includes locker room supervision and making sure athletes are picked up after practices and contests. 6. Know and enforce the rules and regulations required by Title IX, FHSAA, and the Duval County School Board. 7. Monitor academic progress of each team member on a weekly basis. 8. Organizes practice and game responsibilities that are clear and understood by all involved; provides specific duties for coaching throughout the program: primary and extra-duty assignment. 9. Report injuries of participants to the athletic trainer and/or Jacksonville Sports Medicine Program as well as complete a Student Accident Report Form. Following injuries of a serious nature, the coach will secure the signed approval of the doctor and parents before the student is allowed to again participate in athletic activities. (Return to Play form). 10. Support and be an active participant in striving to improve the athletic program as well as the total educational program of the schools. 11. Performs other duties as assigned.

Knowledge of the sport and the strategies associated with the sport Strong oral, written, and interpersonal communication skills Strong word processing, spreadsheet, and presentation software skills Strong leadership skills Strong creative problem solving skills Strong time management skills Strong organizational skills Ability to conduct staff meetings and be in charge of all tryouts, practices, team meetings, and athletic contests for the sport. Ability to be a role model for all student-athletes by conducting your behavior in a professional manner at all times Ability to motivate student-athletes to produce their best effort and results Job Requirements Citizenship, residency or work visa required

Job.JobDescription:
Job Summary:
A high school assistant coach has many responsibilities. A summary and listing of some of those responsibilities are outlined below. The assistant coach will:
1. Support the head coach in conducting a parent/student/coach meeting at the beginning of each season. At that meeting, have written guidelines/handbook available for the parents and students that outlines your practice, attendance, lettering criteria, participation policies and behavior expectations for your players/participants. This should include a document signed by parents and participants agreeing to the information presented. 2. Communicate effectively and regularly with the head coach, student participants/team members, their parents and program coaches/sponsors so that expectations and procedure are clear. 3. Provide and continually update the head coach, or athletic director as to any issues in your program. 4. Never allow an athlete/participant to practice or play/participate until cleared by the SSHS Athletic Department. 5. Follow and uphold all Steamboat Springs High School eligibility policies and procedures, maintain current CHSAA coaching registration, current first aide certification and successfully pass the CHSAA coaching test and NFHS concussion course each school year. 6. Always conduct themselves in an ethical and professional manner and promote to the team/group members a healthy lifestyle with respect to use/abuse of drugs, alcohol, tobacco and steroids. 7. Operate with the understanding and requirement that they are a supervising adult for all athletic or other activity participation at the school and also from the time the team/group leaves the school until all students have been picked up by their parents upon return of the team/group. 8. Take ownership for the care and security of your program equipment. Follow the uniform/equipment check out procedures and account for all student use and support the head coach to collect, inventory and properly store all uniforms/equipment within two weeks of the end of the season. 9. Support the head coach in conducting an end of season awards ceremony to recognize the hard work of the students such as lettering, league and state awards and special accomplishments. Also, use the occasion as a way of thanking your other coaches/sponsors and parents for their assistance during the season/activity period. 10. Represent and advocate for our high school and your sport/activity by attending appropriate league, region and state meetings, as well as clinics, SSHS leadership seminars and professional development opportunities.
Qualifications:
It is the responsibility of the Asst. Head Coach to meet the Coaching Certification requirements of the State of Colorado, Steamboat Springs High School, and the Colorado High School Activities Association (CHSAA), and to perform the services prescribed for this position by the Board of Education or its designated representative.
High School diploma or equivalent Experience in competitive sports preferred Ability to maintain discipline with large groups of students Ability to work independently without direct supervision Excellent interpersonal and communication skills for interacting with students, staff, co-workers, administrators and parents. Physically able to perform the following on a daily basis Ability to lift items weighing 50 pounds from floor level to an elevation of four feet Ability to stand for long periods of time, withstand frequent pushing, pulling, squatting, and reaching Ability to withstand exposure to the outdoor elements including extreme cold, extreme heat, rain, snow and other mountain climatic conditions Possess sufficient manual dexterity and eye-hand coordination to perform responsibilities as described Ability to maintain confidentiality
Application Procedure: Apply Online; all offers of employment are contingent upon the successful completion of a CBI/FBI background check.

Job.JobDescription:
QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to assist in organizing and supervising a sports program. 2. Has previous coaching or athletic experience in assigned sport. 3. The assistant coach must have knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and be willing to learn new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The assistant coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions. 5. Must pay for and pass a background check. 6. CHSAA certification will be required after hire if not already certified (yearly certification and coach's tests). The school will cover this charge. 7. CPR/First Aid/AED certification will be required after hire if not already certified (good for two years). The school will cover this charge. 8. Concussion certification will be required after hire if not already certified (yearly certification and coach's tests). The school will cover this charge.
REPORTS TO: The head coach and athletic director, who provide overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principals. SUPERVISES: May assist in supervising student managers, assistants, and statisticians as directed by the head coach. JOB GOAL: To assist the head coach in instructing athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy, and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. To support the head coach in demonstrating behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self-discipline, self-confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc. GENERAL: 1. The success of athletic programs has a strong influence on the community's image of the entire system. Public exposure is a considerable responsibility and community/parent pressure for winning performance is taxing but must not override the objectives of good sportsmanship and good mental health. 2. The position includes other unusual aspects such as extended time, risk injury factor and due process predicaments. 3. It is the express intent of this job description to give sufficient guidance to function. In cases not specifically covered, it shall be assumed that an assistant coach shall exercise common sense and good judgment. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: 1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Custer County School District's Board of Education and assists in their implementation. 2. Has knowledge of existing system, state and league regulations and implements them consistently. 3. Understands the proper administrative line of command and refers all requests or grievances through proper channels. Is aware of all public/staff/departmental meetings that require attendance. STAFF RESPONSIBILITIES: 1. Assists in implementing the fundamental philosophy, skills and techniques as directed by the head coach. 2. Attends staff meetings and clinics as required. 3. Carries out specific duties as assigned by the head coach. 4. Helps maintain discipline and works to increase morale and cooperation. 5. Performs such other duties which may be assigned by the head coach or athletic director/principal. ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES: 1. Assists the head coach and athletic director in scheduling, providing transportation and requirements for tournament and special sport events. 2. Helps in the necessary preparation to hold scheduled sport events or practices and adheres to scheduled facility times. 3. Assists in providing documentation to fulfill state and system requirements concerning physical examinations, parental consent and eligibility. 4. Helps provide proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment sites. STUDENT RESPONSIBILITIES: 1. Serves as a mentor to each athlete to promote the development and demonstration in student athletes of the character traits of trustworthiness, respect, responsibility, fairness, caring, and citizenship. 2. Assists in monitoring student athletes' grades and conduct. 3. By his/her presence at all practices, games and while traveling, provides assistance, guidance, and safeguards for each participant. 4. Helps enforce training rules and any other unique regulations of the sport for each athlete who is considered a participant. 5. Assists in implementing programs and policies concerning injuries, medical attention and emergencies. 6. Helps complete paperwork on all disabling athletic injuries on proper forms and submits to the athletic office within 24 hours. 7. Assists in directing student managers, assistants and statisticians. 8. Supports the head coach in determining discipline and procedures concerning due process when the enforcement of discipline is necessary. FINANCE AND EQUIPMENT: 1. Assists in the necessary preparation to hold scheduled sport events or practices and adheres to scheduled facility times. 2. Is accountable for all equipment. 3. Assists in examining locker rooms before and after practices and games, checking on general cleanliness of the facility. 4. Helps secure all doors, lights, windows and locks before leaving the building if custodians are not on duty. 5. Supports the head coach in instilling in each player a respect for equipment and school property, its care and proper use. PUBLIC RELATIONS: 1. Assists the head coach in organizing parents, coaches, players and guests for preseason meetings. 2. Helps promote the sport within the school and supports the head coach in recruiting athletes who are not in another sports program.
COMPENSATION: Stipend paid out after sport season ends.
Job.SalaryRange: Stipend paid out after sport season ends

This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Asst. Girls Soccer Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Loveland High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Asst. Girls Soccer Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Asst. Girls Soccer Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Asst. Girls Soccer Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Loveland High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The Head Girls Tennis Coach role at Loveland High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Head Girls Tennis Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Loveland High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Head Girls Tennis Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Head Girls Tennis Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Head Girls Tennis Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Loveland High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Head Girls Tennis Coach at Loveland High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: MS Assistant Track and Field Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The MS Assistant Track and Field Coach position at Peakview Academy at Conrad Ball is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the MS Assistant Track and Field Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The MS Assistant Track and Field Coach at Peakview Academy at Conrad Ball sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Peakview Academy at Conrad Ball, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The MS Assistant Track and Field Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The MS Assistant Track and Field Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the MS Assistant Track and Field Coach position at Peakview Academy at Conrad Ball is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

ASSISTANT COACH SECONDARY EDUCATION JOB DESCRIPTION
JOB TITLE: Assistant Coach REPORTS TO: Head Coach LOCATION: Assigned Building FLSA STATUS: Exempt PAY GRADE: Supplemental DAYS: Length of Season JOB ID & DATE: ATH- 02 | Rev. November, 2022
JOB PURPOSE SUMMARY Assistant athletic coaches instruct and work with athletes to prepare them for competition. Coaches help athletes to play their best individually or as a team in sports such as football, baseball, basketball, track and field, golf, tennis, and soccer. They are experts on the rules, strategies, and techniques of their sports. Coaches must also know about sports equipment, physical fitness and safety.
REQUIREMENTS Education Level Details High school diploma or equivalent. Must meet the CHSAA coaching requirements. Must complete the District’s “Coaching/Sponsor” packet. Must complete the District’s “Volunteer” packet. Must complete annual CPR/First Aide certification courses
Licensure/Certification Details None
Experience Details One year of coaching experience is preferred.
Other Skills and Abilities Required Must be knowledgeable of proper fitness and conditioning techniques necessary for athletes. Must possess a strong comprehensive knowledge of the sport, preferably having participated in the sport at a collegiate or professional level.
EVALUATION Performance will be evaluated annually by the building/District Athletic Director.
COMPENSATION Coaches will be placed on the Supplemental Pay Schedule, based on years of experience for this position, per Article 11-3 of the Classroom Teachers' Association Certified Agreement.
KEY FUNCTIONS, ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES • Fulfill the responsibilities of his/her teaching assignment as a first priority, if a district teacher. • Coach students in the fundamentals and techniques of the sport, in sportsmanship, and proper place of sports in learning discipline and team cooperation. • Adhere to the rules, regulations, stipulations, and policies of the Colorado High School Activities Association, National Federation rules, and Adams County School District 14. • Assist with supervision of athletes and adjunct personnel assigned to the team. • Communicate special needs to the head coach. • Be fair and consistent in all decisions and judgments related to the sport participants. • Perform other duties as prescribed by the Athletic Director.
Communication • Establish and maintain a professional relationship and open communication with parents, students, colleagues, and community members.
Professional Growth and Development • Attend clinics and conferences to keep updated on current trends in the sport.
Policy, Reports, and Law • Comply with policies established by federal and state law, State Board of Education rule, and local Board policy. • Comply with all district and campus routines and regulations. • Perform other duties as assigned by the Athletic Director.
SUPERVISORY RESPONSIBILITIES • Athletes
PHYSICAL REQUIREMENTS/WORKING CONDITIONS Environment: The work environment characteristics and physical demands described here are representative of those an employee encounters while performing the essential functions of this job. Reasonable Accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. Movement: The position requires walking, running, standing, sitting, bending, stooping, kneeling, crouching, crawling. Physical: The employee is regularly required to use hands to finger, handle, or feel objects, tools, or controls; reach with hands and arms; and talk or hear. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision, color vision, and the ability to adjust focus. Work involves everyday risks and discomforts which require normal safety precautions when operating equipment or performing job duties. May work prolonged or irregular hours and must be able to maintain emotional control under stress. The position requires lifting/carrying work related items typically weighing less than 40 pounds. Location: Work is performed in gyms, offices, locker rooms, weight rooms, on athletic fields, buses, etc. May work prolonged or irregular hours and must be able to maintain control under stress. The position requires travel to various campuses, district meeting sites and conferences/meetings in and out of state. The position may require the employee to work some evenings and weekends.
STATEMENT OF UNDERSTANDING I understand, the above statements are intended to describe major job functions of this position and are not intended to represent an exhaustive list of all responsibilities, duties, and skills required. The Superintendent or designee may assign additional duties when deemed appropriate. Special Funding: If my position is funded by grants, federal funding, or other special funding, I understand that my employment is expressly conditioned on the availability of full funding for the position. If full funding becomes unavailable my employment is subject to termination, non-renewal, or reassignment as applicable.
To perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed to the job description are representative of the knowledge, skills, ability, and physical demands required. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential job functions.

Job.JobTitle: High School Girls Wrestling Assistant Coach
Job.JobDescription:
Job Title: High School Girls' Wrestling Assistant Coach Reports to: High School Girls' Wrestling Head Coach Salary: $1,600 - $1,900 Work year: Seasonal
Job Summary: Join our staff as the high school girls' wrestling assistant coach and lead a team of highly dedicated student athletes. The assistant wrestling coach promotes an appreciation of physical fitness, teamwork and sportsmanship.
Qualifications:
High school diploma or equivalent. A teacher with a current teaching license is preferred but not a requirement. Current CPR and AED Certification. Previous coaching experience in this sport at the high school level is desirable. Have a valid driver’s license, be able to drive, and qualify under the district’s insurance carrier when driving a district vehicle. Desire to continue career improvement. Excellent oral and verbal communication skills. Proven problem-solving skills.
Essential Functions:
Assists the head coach with instructing players in the rules, regulations, equipment, and techniques of the sport. Organizes and directs individual and small group practice activities/exercises as directed by the head coach. Assesses player’s skills, monitors players during competition and practice, and keeps the head wrestling coach informed of the athletic performance of students. Assists with determining game strategy. Assists the head coach with supervising athletes during practices and competition. Models sports-like behavior and maintains appropriate conduct towards players, officials, and spectators. Maintains the equipment room in orderly condition and assumes responsibility for its security. Distributes equipment, supplies, and uniforms to students as directed by the head coach. Promote an appreciation of physical fitness, teamwork, and sportsmanship. Support the value of an education. Help students achieve gains in athletic skill and team performance. Maintain good public relations for the wrestling program. Ensure that health and safety precautions are observed during all activities. Follow school, league, district, and CHSAA regulations and policies. Other responsibilities as assigned.
Questions regarding this position, please contact Josh Pedersen, Activity and Athletic Director, pedersenj@wgsd.us or 970-724-3425
Questions regarding the application process, please contact Martha Schake, Director of Finance and Human Resource at schakem@wgsd.us or 970-724-1007

Job.JobDescription:
The Head Coach-Volleyball-Girls role at Broomfield High emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Head Coach-Volleyball-Girls coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Broomfield High, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Head Coach-Volleyball-Girls reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Broomfield High at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Head Coach-Volleyball-Girls may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Head Coach-Volleyball-Girls monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Head Coach-Volleyball-Girls must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Broomfield High.

This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The 25/26 Girls' Basketball Specialist, Escalante Middle School is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Escalante Middle School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The 25/26 Girls' Basketball Specialist, Escalante Middle School encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The 25/26 Girls' Basketball Specialist, Escalante Middle School also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the 25/26 Girls' Basketball Specialist, Escalante Middle School role at Escalante Middle School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: Track and Field Head Varsity Coach (Summit High School)
Job.JobDescription:
The Track and Field Head Varsity Coach (Summit High School) at Summit High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Track and Field Head Varsity Coach (Summit High School) is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Summit High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Track and Field Head Varsity Coach (Summit High School) helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Track and Field Head Varsity Coach (Summit High School) works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Summit High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Summit High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Track and Field Head Varsity Coach (Summit High School) reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Track and Field Head Varsity Coach (Summit High School) role at Summit High School.

Job.JobDescription:
The Head Coach - Boys Tennis at Gulf High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Head Coach - Boys Tennis is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Gulf High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Head Coach - Boys Tennis helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Head Coach - Boys Tennis works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Gulf High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Gulf High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Head Coach - Boys Tennis reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Head Coach - Boys Tennis role at Gulf High School.

The Head Coach - Weightlifting & Powerlifting at Casa Grande Union High School District 82 is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Head Coach - Weightlifting & Powerlifting manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Casa Grande Union High School District 82, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Head Coach - Weightlifting & Powerlifting demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Head Coach - Weightlifting & Powerlifting follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Head Coach - Weightlifting & Powerlifting at Casa Grande Union High School District 82 allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobDescription:
The Esports Coach position at Safford Unif School District 1 is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Esports Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Safford Unif School District 1, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Esports Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Esports Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Esports Coach role at Safford Unif School District 1 is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The MHS Head Golf Coach - Varsity position at Nadaburg Unified is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the MHS Head Golf Coach - Varsity works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The MHS Head Golf Coach - Varsity at Nadaburg Unified sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Nadaburg Unified, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The MHS Head Golf Coach - Varsity encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The MHS Head Golf Coach - Varsity is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the MHS Head Golf Coach - Varsity position at Nadaburg Unified is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobDescription:
Position Summary Under the general direction/supervision of the Athletic Director and Principal, assumes responsibility for planning and administering specified sports programs and related activities including coaching an athletic team and performing other duties directly related to this position description. Duties & Responsibilities
Provide coordination and supervision of the sports program and team. Help students achieve gains in athletic skill and team performance. Designs a training program and game program. Organizes and supervises the coaching staff to assure that the program is properly implemented Develops team rules, communicating them to the players and their parents, and equitably enforce them. Ensures that student athletes meet eligibility rules. Ensure that student athletes adhere to training rules, lettering policies, grade requirements, and rules of behavior. Ensure the continual supervision of student athletes on the field, in conditioning, and in locker and shower rooms. Ensure that health and safety precautions are observed during all activities. Immediately report all major injuries incurred during practice sessions or competition to the Athletic Director and Principal. Assist in the proper purchasing, inventory, and care of equipment. See that district policies are observed during all activities. Keep abreast of new information, innovative ideas and techniques. Obtain advance approval of the Athletic Director and/or Principal for all activities and expenditures. Other duties as assigned by the Athletic Director and/or Principal.
Qualifications, Competencies & Strengths Education: High School Diploma or equivalent; Bachelor’s degree preferred. Experience: 1-2 years of experience as a working as athletic coach in an academic setting is preferred Special Skills:
NFHS and Concussion certified required Demonstrated ability to participate in physically demanding athletic activities Possesses knowledge of effective behavior management methods Ability to exercise good judgment and work in a dynamic environment Professional and friendly disposition
Type of fingerprint clearance: Shall be fingerprint checked pursuant to A.R.S 15-512 Physical functions: While performing the duties of this job, the employee is regularly required to talk or hear. The employee is frequently required to walk; run; jump; stretch; stand; sit; use hands for fine manipulation, handle or feel and reach with hands and arms. The employee is occasionally required to stoop, kneel, crouch or crawl. The employee must regularly lift and/or move up to 50 pounds and occasionally up to 100 pounds. The employee may occasionally climb stairs, ropes or ladders. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision, distance vision, ability to adjust focus and peripheral vision. The employee must have the ability to demonstrate proper techniques and skills needed for athletic participation. Equipment used: Athletic and weight training equipment Work Environment: The work environment is a standard athletic practice venue and event settings. The noise level in the work environment is usually moderate but occasionally high depending upon student population and activities. The employee is regularly exposed to hot outdoor weather conditions. The employee may be exposed to bodily fluids and/or bloodborne pathogens. Travel: This position requires the ability to travel to and from school events and activities. Must be available to accompany team to sporting events.
Equal Opportunity Employer

Position Type: Athletics/Activities/Coaching Date Posted: 10/23/2025 Location: Colonel Smith Middle School JOB TITLE: Coach DEPARTMENT: Colonel Smith Middle School REPORTS TO: Athletic Director FLSA STATUS/CLASSIFICATION: Exempt SUPERVISORY DUTIES: none SUMMARY: Position is responsible for coaching student-athletes in-game strategies and techniques to prepare them for athletic competition. Position motivates student-athletes to develop an appreciation of the sport. ESSENTIAL DUTIES & RESPONSIBILITIES: Coaches and instructs players, individually or in groups, regarding the rules, sportsmanship, equipment, and fundamental skills/techniques of the sport. Observes players, during competition and practice to determine the needs for individual or team improvement. Holds organizational meetings for team prospects and encourages potential athletes to participate in the sport. Assesses player’s skills and assigns team positions. Develops a regular practice schedule and organizes practice time to provide both individual and team development. Works with the athletics director in scheduling facilities for practices and competition. Assigns duties to an assistant coach as necessary. Determines the game strategy based on the team’s capabilities. Establishes and maintains standards of pupil behavior and provides proper supervision of athletes at all times. Monitors the academic performance of team members to ensure that eligibility requirements are met, and encourages student-athletes to maintain a high academic standard. Follows established procedures in the event of an athlete’s injury. Conferences with parents/guardians, as necessary, regarding the athletic performance of their student. Follows state, regional, and district regulations governing the athletic program. Models sportsmanship-like behavior and maintain appropriate conduct towards players, officials, and spectators. Follows established procedures for the proper care, maintenance, and requisitioning of equipment, supplies, and uniforms. Maintains required or related records. Models nondiscriminatory practices in all activities. Each coach is expected to provide the principal and members of their squad with a copy of the rules that govern their practice, game, and travel. KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS & ABILITIES: Knowledge of applicable rules, strategy, and skillsets required for success. Ability to teach/instruct the fundamentals of the sport Ability to work effectively with students and staff Ability to maintain confidentiality Ability to communicate effectively verbally and in writing Ability to work cooperatively and courteously with staff, students, parents, and community members Knowledge of applicable Federal and State laws, district procedures and Board policies QUALIFICATIONS & REQUIREMENTS: Education & Experience: A minimum of 1-year coaching experience Teaching Certificate preferred Criminal Justice/Fingerprint clearance Maintain requirements for access to Fort Huachuca Any equivalent combination of training, education, and experience that meets minimum requirements Computer Proficiency: Demonstrated general proficiency in computer programs such as Microsoft Excel, Word, and Outlook. PHYSICAL DEMANDS: The physical demands described here are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of the job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. The physical demands described here are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. While performing the duties of this job, the employee is regularly required to stand; walk; sit; use hands to finger, handle, or feel; reach with hands and arms, and talk or hear. The employee may be required to climb, balance, stoop, kneel, crouch, or crawl. The employee may have to lift and/or move up to 50 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision, distance vision, peripheral vision, and ability to adjust focus. WORK ENVIRONMENT: The work environment characteristics described here are representative of those an employee encounters while performing essential functions of the job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. Duties are normally performed in a school environment or outdoors. Duties may be performed away from school. The noise level in the work environment is usually moderate to loud. The Assistant Track Coach - EVHS position at Eagle Valley High School - Gypsum is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Assistant Track Coach - EVHS is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Eagle Valley High School - Gypsum, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Assistant Track Coach - EVHS encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Assistant Track Coach - EVHS also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Assistant Track Coach - EVHS role at Eagle Valley High School - Gypsum is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.
